title: Ricky Woznichak
text:
Iâ€™m Ricky Woznichak, a passionate digital marketing professional and current M.S. candidate in Digital Marketing at Cal Poly Pomona. Prior to my stint as an actor, I cut my teeth as an Assistant Digital Media Planner at UM, crafting campaigns for clients like Sony Home Entertainment and IHOP. Along the way I also honed my storytelling and people skills as a substitute teacher andâ€”true storyâ€”an awesome waiter. Iâ€™ve led SEO initiatives, mastered tools like Google Analytics and SEMrush, and built interactive R and Quarto dashboards that turn complex insights into clear action. When Iâ€™m not geeking out over forecasting models for my Productfolio.com thesis, youâ€™ll find me strolling with my dog Jimmy â€” because great ideas often strike when youâ€™re off screen.
You can find my entire journey on Linkedin - Letâ€™s Connect!

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
We can create a summary table and modify it for various statistical analyses using the {gtsummary} package.



Versatile Output: Supports summary statistics, regression models, survival analysis, and more â€” all formatted beautifully.
Customizable: Easily change labels, statistics, and formatting without needing to manually tweak tables.
Publication-Ready: Outputs clean, APA-style tables with minimal effort â€” ideal for reports, papers, and presentations.
Reproducibility: Tables are generated directly from your analysis pipeline, reducing the risk of transcription errors.

Create polished tables for homework, theses, or presentations.

In Your Career:

Quickly generate high-quality tables for client reports, internal documents, or academic publications.
Streamline analysis workflows with reproducible and automated reporting.
Integrate with tools like Quarto, R Markdown, and Shiny apps for interactive or dynamic reporting.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
section: How does gtsummary differ from gt and gtExtras?
text: How does gtsummary differ from gt and gtExtras?

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
gt

Purpose:Â A core package for creatingÂ flexible and beautiful tablesÂ in R.
Strength:Â Great forÂ custom-designed tablesÂ from scratch, especially for presenting summary stats, formatted text, etc.
Usage:Â You have toÂ manually defineÂ your data transformations and table formatting.
Think of it as:Â A powerful table engine, similar toÂ ggplot2Â but for tables.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
gtExtras

Purpose:Â A set ofÂ helper functionsÂ that work on top ofÂ gtÂ toÂ make common formatting tasks easier.
Strength:Â Adds shortcuts for enhancements like:

Heatmaps
Sparklines
Fancy styling presets

Usage:Â It extendsÂ gtÂ and saves time on visual and layout improvements.
Think of it as:Â Add-ons to style and beautify yourÂ gtÂ tables quickly.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
gtsummary

Purpose:Â Built specifically forÂ statistical reporting and clinical-style summary tables.
Strengths:

Automatically identifies variable types (continuous, categorical, dichotomous).
BuildsÂ â€œTable 1â€-style summariesÂ with a single line of code.
Easily adds:

P-values (add_p())
Confidence intervals
Regression summaries (tbl_regression())
Inline reporting

Highly customizable usingÂ tidyselectÂ syntax.

UsesÂ gtÂ under the hoodÂ for the table rendering.
Think of it as:Â AÂ reporting-focused abstraction layerÂ that does 90% of the formatting and logic for you.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
Inline Reporting with inline_text()

You canÂ pull values directly from a table into your R Markdown textÂ â€” like odds ratios, p-values, or confidence intervals.
Example:
"The odds ratio for age isr inline_text(tbl, variable = â€œageâ€)."
Keeps yourÂ results synced automaticallyÂ with your tables â€” no manual copy-paste needed!

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
Formula Syntax for Customizing Variables

Customize labels, types, stats, and digits usingÂ formula-like syntaxÂ (e.g.,Â variable ~ value).
Supports tidyselect helpers likeÂ all_continuous(),Â starts_with("age"), etc.
Lets youÂ target multiple variables with one lineÂ for streamlined styling.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
section: Merge and Stack Tables Easily (tbl_merge(), tbl_stack())
text:
Merge and Stack Tables Easily (tbl_merge(), tbl_stack())

Combine multiple tables:

Side-by-side (e.g., univariable vs.Â multivariable regression)
Top-to-bottom (e.g., adjusted vs.Â unadjusted estimates)

Helps youÂ build complex, publication-quality tablesÂ without breaking a sweat.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text: Gtsummary Chart

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
The P-Value:
A p-value of 0.001 from the Chi-square test suggests that there is a statistically significant association between keyword intent and ranking position for productfolio.com. Considering that the p-value is much lower than 0.05, which is the commonly used significance level, we reject the null hypothesis that there is no relationship between keyword intent and position. Stated differently, certain keyword intent types (informational, commercial, etc.) meaningfully influence where Google search results rank websites. This means that some keywords may attract higher traffic than others for this domain niche, and this information can be used in future content planning or SEO.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text: Thank You Very Much

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
4.2 The P-Value:
A p-value of 0.001 from the Chi-square test suggests that there is a statistically significant association between keyword intent and ranking position for productfolio.com. Considering that the p-value is much lower than 0.05, which is the commonly used significance level, we reject the null hypothesis that there is no relationship between keyword intent and position. Stated differently, certain keyword intent types (informational, commercial, etc.) meaningfully influence where Google search results rank websites. This means that some keywords may attract higher traffic than others for this domain niche, and this information can be used in future content planning or SEO.
